George Allen. England. died (recently) Ruskin's Publishers. Liberty: 1907, Vol XVI No. 4. 400 October Tucker in mentioning his death speaks of having started in search of an edition of Ruskin ("33 years ago") 1874 when he went to England. Tucker went to Kent to find an edition of Ruskin, boycotted at the time. He found George Allen. Mr. Ruskin was in Italy. Mr. Allen gave him a set of Ruskin and a portrait & autographed letter and other things greatly
[reverse] prized by the 20 year old Tucker. (It is a reference that throws light on his 1874 stay in Europe.)

Altgeld, John Peter. Material saved by George A. Schilling and given by Harry Barnard in 1940-1941
Sent to Agnes Inglis - Labadie Collection When the Illinois State Historical Library at Springfield, Illinois decided to establish a Memorial Center to John Peter Altgeld to assemble all material possible on Altgeld, both Harry Barnard and Agnes Inglis agreed the Schilling Material belonged in Illinois with the Altgeld material. I, therefore, went over it, keeping duplicates, having originals photostated, to keep. Keeping only a over
[reverse] few things for the Labadie Collection saved by George A. Schilling that had some personal or historic relation to either Schilling or Altgeld. The rest all went back to Illinois. Sent to the Librarian, Mr. Paul Angle signed: Agnes Inglis May 4, 1941

John Peter Altgeld (1847-1902) Governor of Illinois. In 1893 he freed from prison three men, life-time prisoners, accused, in 1886, of having had a part in the Haymarket affair. He both freed them and affirmed their innocence. A book published in 1938 brought Altgeld again into prominence. The book is entitled "Eagle Forgotten: The Life of John Peter Altgeld," by Harry Barnard. Bobbs-Merrill Company publishers, Indianapolis and New York.

Alwato was a "scientific" language invented by Stephen Pearl Andrews. Ref: The primary synopsis of universology and Alwato : the new scientific universal language / by Stephen Pearl Andrews. Pub. New York : D. Thomas, 1871.

Liberty, July 11, 1891 [clipping] The Science of Society by Stephen Pearl Andrews. This work, long out of print, is now republished to meet a demand which for a few years past has been rapidly growing. First published about forty years ago, and yet in its teachings still far in advance of the times, it comes to the present generation practically as a new book. Josiah Warren, whose social philosophy it was written to expound, was in the habit of referring to it as the most lucid and complete presentation of this ideas that ever had been written or ever could be written. It will undoubtedly take rank in the future among the famous books of the nineteenth century. It consists of two parts, as follows: Part I. The True Constitution of Government in the Sovereignty of the Individual as the Final Development of Protestantism, Democracy, and Socialism. Part II. Cost the Limit of Price: A Scientific Measure of Honesty in Trade, as one of the Fundamental Principles in the Solution of the Social Problem. Price, in Cloth, One Dollar. Address the Publisher: Sarah E. Holmes, Box 3366, Boston, Mass.
Stephen Pearl Andrews Woodhull & Claflin's Weekly. No. 12, July 30, 1870. The Pantarchy. Formal nomination of S.P.A. as Pantarch

Stephen Pearl Andrews References: Dictionary of American Biography. Interest in Simplified Spelling and International Language. Invented "Alwato." See Envelope "S.P.A." - Libertarian people file case. See Libertarian Section: Esperanto, Ido and Alwato, International Languages. See John R. Commons Collection at Madison. See Woodhull & Claflin's Weekly. Free Thought and Woman Movement Section. See file case envelope for his photograph.

Stephen Pearl Andrews 1876. "The Index." Following the discussion over Proudhon in the Index between Stephen Pearl Andrews and Benj. R. Tucker - and Wm. B. Greene, on the side of Tucker and Proudhon, the Index printed a series of communications in issues of Oct. 26, Nov. 23, and Dec. 14th, 1876 by Stephen Pearl Andrews under the heading "The Science of Universology," 1, 2 & 3. He does this at the request of Mr. Greene. These clippings he saved: they are in his "Envelope" Libertarian People file case. The discussion ended August 10th, 1876.
STEPHEN PEARL ANDREWS. in 1884. Addressed the "LIBERAL CLUB, NYC" REF: HOME JOURNAL, AUGUST 20th 1884 He saved a clipping of this address. It is in his "ENVELOPE."

Stephen Pearl Andrews "The Sovereignty of the Individual" by Stephen Pearl Andrews Reprinted in 1891 June 3, Whole No. 55 of the Woodhull & Claflin's Weekly together with an explanation of its first printing "nearly twenty years ago," which first printing as a Pamphlet, had been saved by Josiah Warren, whose ideas the article embodied. Note: This first printing in pamphlet form would, seemingly, have been in 1851. over
[reverse] In 1857, at any rate, the article was reprinted (or printed) in one of Josiah Warren's "Periodical Letters," namely Second Series Vol. I No. 6, Sept. 1857, at Long Island, NY. (Modern Times) Reprinted from the 1857 Periodical Letter, it appears as a 20 page small pamphlet, printed in Berkeley Heights, NJ, as the Freeman Press by Anitole Freeman Ishill, in February 1938 See listing of this pamphlet.

Who was "Senex"? Who went to hear Stephen Pearl Andrews at home of Beecher "about seventeen or eighteen years ago (1854) when 3 parlors were filled early one evening with people, mostly of Mr. Beecher's church." Woodhull & Claflin's Weekly, 1873 Feb. 8 Vol. 5 No. 9, Whole No. 114, p. 9/10, about 1854 1873-18=1854 or 1855 Gathering was in Mr. Beecher's home. Mr. Beecher called the meeting to order. Senex was a mentor of Mr. Beecher's congregation as he writes in 1873--about 80 persons sat in the parlors and heard
[reverse] Stephen Pearl Andrews, 1854/1855. Andrews talked 2 1/2 hours, a remarkable speed.

Stephen Pearl Andrews and Josiah Warren and "The Science of Society"
Stephen Pearl Andrews tells about 1851. Reference: Woodhull & Claflin's Weekly, 1871, August 5th "I became acquainted with Mr. Warren's peculiar and invaluable scheme of socialist ideas in 1851: and I write and published that same year, I believe, a word entitled 'Science of Society', now out of type, which was little more than my exposition of his ideas." *** S.P.A. Andrews goes on to say he agreed with these ideas, although not always agreeing with Warren on other subjects.

Antolini, Gabriella. "Ella" Anarchist See Appeal to Reason, 1920 Sept. 4 Article by Kate Richards O'Hare on prisons in which she speaks of Ella and of Mollie Steimer - both in prison in Jefferson City with her and Emma Goldman See Anarchist Cat. "People"

Antolini, Gabriella, called "Ella" Anarchist Arrested in connection with the war and the Minneapolis case of 1917 or 1918 and put in Jefferson City. See Appeal to Reason 1920 Sept. 4 - an article by Kate Richards O'Hare on prisons in which she speaks of Ella and of Mollie Steimer, both in prison with Emma Goldman and Kate O'Hare. Ella lived in Detroit in 1920-1922.

Antoline, Ella. See the "Milwaukee Case" of Sept 9 1918 See "Mother Earth Bulletin" after Sept 9 1918 about the Milwaukee Case. Ella's case followed this case and was connected with it. Ella Antoline was in Jefferson City with Emma Goldman and Kate O'Hare. See Emma Goldman's Correspondence while in prison.

Antolini, Gabriella. "Ella" See Appeal to Reason, 1920 Sept. 4 Article by Kate Richards O'Hare on prisons in which she speaks of Ella and of Mollie Steimer. Ella lived in Detroit in 1920-1922, had a baby there. She worked with the Sacco-Vanzetti Anarchist Italian Group.

[handwritten] Antolini, Ella. 804 Withersfield Street Hartford, Conn. Pomilia, 1922 "Venchy": name in 1947
[typed] In 1920-1921 and on at that time Ella was living in Detroit, and had her baby. She was arrested after the Milwaukee frame-up and served, I think, 18 mos in Jefferson City when Emma Goldman and Kate O'Hare were in prison.

Febo A. Pomilia Son of Ella Antolini (Mrs. Pomilia) Ella Antolini Pomilia married a second time and in Feb 1947 when Febo came to Ann Arbor and saw Agnes Inglis and the Labadie Collection he was 25 years of age. I saw him in 1922 as a baby. Agnes Inglis, Feb. 28 1947
443 Central Ave. Needham/Leylis Mass.

Ella Antolini Married Mr. Pomilia in Detroit either in 1921 or 1922. Her son Febo A. Pomilia was born in 1922. Ella, later, married a second time, and is now (1947) Mrs. Ella Venchy. Febo visited Agnes Inglis and the Labadie Collection Feb. 25, 26, 27, 1947.

Organe d'education de realization de camaradie individualiste anarchiste Issues 1922-1939, Nos. 1-335, complete Note: E. Armand edited "l'Era Nouvelle" 1901-1906; "Les Refractaires" 1912-1914; "Par dela la melee", 1916-1918; so his publications ran from 1901-1939. The last issue of "L'en dehors" is no. 335, October 1939, consisting of one page of one sheet, giving an account of "L'en dehors" and its predecessors, some of which are in the Collection. He is also the author and publisher of many books and pamphlets which he has donated
[reverse] to the Collection. His first donations were to Joe Labadie. Some of Joe Labadie's poems he translated and published in his publications; he was, himself, a poet. After Joe Labadie's death he donated his works directly to the Collection - up to October, 1939

E. Armand et son œuvre "Tout le monde n'aime pas E. Armand," écrivait Gérard de Lacaze-Duthiers dan "Le Semeus" du 20 janvier 1926. Ce n'est pas une raison pour le calomnier ou le diffamer, même si le calomniateur ou le diffamateur est la proie du gâtisme sénile. La meilleure réponse, heureusement, aux injures et aux insulttes est dans "l'œuvre" de notre camarade: la voici, cidessous, détaillée de façon aussi complète que possible.

Obituary originally read by de Cleyre at Karg Harker's funeral was read at graveside of Kate Austin (ref: Women public speakers in the United States, 1800-1925: a bio-critical sourcebook By Karlyn Kohrs Campbell, which cites the same issue of Free Society)

Austin, Kate, 1870- Caplinger Mills, Mo. Anarchist from Missouri and Iowa. Agitated among the farmers. Wrote for Free Society, Demonstrator and Lucifer. Ref: Free Society, 1902, Nov. 30 (whole No. 390). An account of her. An article by her on the Woman Movement in her own hand-writing, never published, in her Envelope, Anarchist People.

Austin, Sam. Route 5, Stocton, Mo. Sent material thru Carl Nold. He was the husband of Kate Austin. See Kate Austin Envelope with Anarchist People. See Living My Life Envelope for letter to Carl Nold from Jennie Austin. Whinrey Milling Co. Missouri

Badcock, John Jr. Personal Rights Ass'n, London, 1893, declined to publish a letter written by John Badcock, Jr. in which he protested against Personal Rights seeking to discredit the Anarchists Liberty. "On Picket Duty". Liberty published the letter, Liberty, Vol. IX, 1893, June 24 (277).

In my research as to what the heading of the card should be, I came across Carlene Bagnall's obituary, dated July 15, 2010. She had earned a PhD in English and Women's Studies at Michigan and later became a professor of Women's Studies at Michigan. She was extensively involved with peace and non-violent activities throughout her life.

Survey Graphic, May 1, 1928 The Daughters of the American Revolution have been saved from becoming the laughing-stock of the country. The New York Times, for instance, made high fun of their blacklist, which came out on the heels of April Fool's Day and solemnly set down "our too, too solid friend William Allen White" of Kansas as a "socialist." Mr. White himself tossed on the ball of ridicule with such delicious trimmings as "tea gladiators" and "nice old girls." But a few days later came a vigorous pamphlet, Our Threatened Heritage, a Letter to the D.A.R., in which Helen Tufts Bailie, of Cambridge, Massachusetts, and fourteen other members protest that "our society has been duped." They point out that the person discriminated against as speakers before chapter meetings "are religious, educational, political and social science leaders," and they deplore the fact that "our splendid organization has become a tail to the kite of ignorant, misguided or designing persons." They trace the list back to the discredited Lusk report, "the activities of the Department of Justice under Palmer, Daugherty and Burns" and Fred R. Marvin of the "Key Men of America." Mrs. Bailie stops the laughter not only by her serious concern for the "fellow-citizens whom we have grossly and unfairly abused," but by her demonstration that the fighting blood among the Daughters is not confined to lobbying for a bigger navy; that there is an insurgent wing which believes in liberties the foremothers thought worth sacrifice.
There is no card. Just a clipping from a publication. The phrase "Mrs. Bailie" in the second half of the article has been underlined.

With a preface by Carlo Cafiero and Elisee Reclus. (First French Edition - "Preface-Geneve, 1882") "A New Edition, Revised from the Original Manuscript" "Introductory Remarks" by M. Nettlau, Nov 24, 1908 in which he says "Benj. R. Tucker's translation forms the basis of the present amended edition."
63 pages - paper-covered book Anarchist Section Box Booklets "Michael Bakunin" over
[reverse] In sending this "Freedom - 1910" edition, Thomas H. Keell writes (Jan. 9 1936) see Correspondence- as follows. "You ask for data about 'God and the State.' The first English translation was by Benj. R. Tucker (Boston 1883). This translation was reprinted by the 'Commonwealth' (London, 1894). 'The Free Society' edition must also have been a reprint of Tucker's translation. In 1910 Freedom Press published 'A New Edition Revised from the Original Manuscript' by M. Nettlau, who wrote an 'Introductory Remark' as a preface, giving the history of the work, and concluding by saying: 'Benj. R. Tucker's translation forms the basis of the present amended edition.' When Emma Goldman published 'God and the State' (1916 or 1917--there is no date on it), she used this amended edition, but did not publish Nettlau's 'Introductory Remark,' much to his disgust, nor was the translator or revisor
Note: The text continues on the next card.

mentioned. To crown everything, on the title-page was printed 'First American edition'!! It certainly was the first American edition of the amended edition, but the ordinary reader would have no idea that an American edition of 'G & S' was published over thirty years before."
See "FREEDOM", England: Vol. XXIV, 1910, No. 249 (January) "God and the State": A new edition revised from the original Manuscript
Note: The text continues Keell's quote from the previous card.

"FIRST AMERICAN EDITION" - 86 pages, paper-covered Mother Earth Publishing Association 20 East 125 St., N.Y.C. (probably in 1916) Note: This was reprinted from the New Edition of M. Nettlau--revised from original manuscript--with an "Introductory Remark" by M. Nettlau, saying "Benj. R. Tucker's translation forms the basis of the present amended edition." In the Mother Earth edition no mention is made of the translator or reviser and this "REMARK" is omitted. Nor is mention made of the 1883 American ed.
[reverse] In regard to the omission of the name of Benj. R. Tucker, as translator, or of Max Nettlau's revision of it. The first, in America, in 1883 and the second in England in 1908-1910. Keell, from England, dated Jan. 9th 1936, regarding the omission of the two names and the omission, also, of Benj. R. Berkman, Alexander Berkman was put out of France on May Day, 1930. The reason was that he was editor of the "Bulletin" for the Political Prisoners in Russia. He was obliged to discontinue the work in order to stay on earth. Once is obliged to stay somewhere on earth while here. So Rudolph Rocker took the editorship of it. See "The Bulletin," 1930, Nov., Dec.

Alexander Berkman and the Labor Leader, as to his act in 1892 at Homestead. Labor Leader, Boston, edited by Frank K. Foster, Vol XIX, 1896, No. 27, July 25. "Our anarchist friends did a very clever piece of propaganda work last Sunday in the Bergman resolutions. The poor crazy devil has probably got his full measure of punishment and if the action of the C.L.U. amounts to anything more than an expression of sentiment there would be more reason possibly for taking it . In reality, it doesn't amount to anything excepting to put the society in a false position before the public."

Berkman In 1892, in Detroit there was a memorial meeting. Nov. 14, 1892. A Detroit paper (having no name on the clipping) reported that Reitzel (Robert) "eulogized Bergman who attempted the life of Frick." Clipping is in the Detroit - Haymarket Envelope "R. Reitzel The Red", 1892
Inglis must have meant to write "Homestead" instead of "Haymarket" in the last line.

Berkman Released from Penitentiary 1906 May 18 See Mother Earth May & June 1906 See Berkman's Prison Memoirs Carl Nold and Emma Goldman "Carl" and the "Girl" met him at the station in Detroit A hand bill in the Collection tells of a meeting in Arbeiter Hall, Russell & Catherine St., Detroit - 1906 May 22, Tuesday: "Alexander Berkman, Emma Goldman, & Others" spoke.

Berkman, Alexander DEMONSTRATOR - Home, Washington. Vol. 3, 1906 May 2 (102), "Cranky Notions" by Joseph A. Labadie, "Carl Nold has taken up his residence in Detroit, for awhile..."
June 6. (104) "Alexander Berkman's First Speech After His Release from Jail." Speech, May 22. Detroit (Printed in full) Note: He was released May 18 and came to Detroit where he was met by Carl Nold and Emma Goldman. In his Prison Memoirs and in E.G.'s Living My Life this is told. Carl Nold came to Detroit in April or May, likely, and at once found things to do - Berkman and then the Haymarket meeting, all in 1906.

Detroit Bowen, Paul T. - attended the Paris Labor Congress (Possibilist) as a delegate - on the four sent from the U.S., 1889 July, and attended also as a delegate the Typo held at the same time and place - July 1889. 1885: The Detroit Labor Leaf says Vol. II No. 3, 1885 November 25th: "Paul T. Bowen (who, by the way is a Michigan man) of Excelsior Assembly, 2672, one of the brightest of the many able men for which that assembly is noted....."

Bowen, Paul T. - (who, by the way, is a Michigan man) of Excelsior Assembly, 2672 one of the brightest of the many able men for which that assembly is noted....etc." signed "LEUMAS" Detroit Labor Leaf, Vol. II, No. 3, November 25, 1885
Note: In 1889 he was one of the four delegates to the Labor Congress at Paris, France, and also to the Typo Congress at that time and place.

Bowen, Paul Tabor Letter to George A. Schilling dated July 24, 1893 - Letterhead, Washington D.C. Office of the Fourth Auditor, Treasury Dept. He wanted from George A. Schilling if possible 300 of 2000 printed pamphlets. He hopes Gov. Altgeld prepares an exhaustive review of the anarchist case & that it will be published. He belongs to the D.A. Knights of Labor in Washington D.C. He speaks of those who stand for the condemned men & of the revival of interest in the case and how it is uniting all groups. It is a fine letter. See Haymarket Case Box.
[reverse] A photostat copy of the original letter is in the Labadie Collection, Haymarket Box of Material: The original letter is with the Altgeld Material in the Illinois State Historical Society Library - Springfield, Illinois.

Steven T. Byington born December 20, 2868 at Benson, Vermont Stickers. Begun in Liberty in 1904 were first originated by Byington at a suggestion from Henry Bool, who requested from Byington "a short, crisp sentence." Byington sent him three such, two of which were later made into stickers. He contracted to many Anarchist publications as the Firebrand of Portland, Oregon: Mother Earth, Liberty, "Man!", Age of Thought, & other Edward H. Fulton pamphlets.
[reverse] He translated "Anarchism" by Dr. Paul Eltzbacher. He translated Der Einzige und sein Eigenthum, named by Benj. R. Tucker in free translation "The Ego and His Oath". He encouraged simplified spelling.

Steven T. Byington and his "Stickers" "Stickers as Starters" by Steven T. Byington "Stickers now exist. The following samples will show the style." address S. T. Byington. Cambridge, Mass. Ref.: "Liberty" Vol. XIV, March and April, 1904, and after that in every issue for a long time.
Steven T. Byington's "Stickers" that started in 1904 continued until after April, 1906, Liberty that month mentions them in "On Picket Duty", Benj. R. Tucker's editorial column, "The Anarchist Stickers devised and pro-
[reverse] duced by Mr. Byington are a highly useful addition to the Anarchist propoganda." By October 1906, however, Liberty has this to say in regard to the stickers: "Mr. Byington's supply of Anarchist stickers being exhausted he has transferred to me the business of manufacturing and supplying them. Hereafter all the stickers will be of the same size, but they will be issued in greater variety. I have retained nearly all the old ones, but have added some new ones suggested by Mr. Byington and other friends, as well as some of my own choice. In all there are now forty-eight. I am printing a million of them."

JOSEPH A. LABADIE and the BYINGTON-TUCKER STICKERS:
Ref.: THE MICHIGAN UNION ADVOCATE, Detroit. Vol. V, 1908, No. 15, April 10th "Labadie's Mail Held By P.O." This paper was only one that took up the matter of whether or not Joe Labadie was to lose his $75 dollar a month job as a clerk in the Water Works because he stuck stickers on his envelopes when he wrote a letter, showing by this that he was--as he was always proud to say he was--an Anarchist. The matter hung fire for weeks and while a serious matter to Joe, all his newspaper friends on all
[reverse] city newspapers stood by him--making a good deal of fun of the attack against Joe. The attack ceased and Joe kept his job. It was just at this time that "Liberty" ceased or "Liberty" would have published the story. The Michigan Union Advocate quotes one of the stickers, "I do not care who makes the laws of a nation, if I can only get out an injunction." -Mr. Dooley"

In the Mirror of St. Louis appeared a review of Stephen T. Byington's English translation of Max Stirner's "The Ego & His Own" - as republished in London, Eng. by A. C. Fifield. Lucy Sterner read this review, and wrote her review of the other review--The original in French of Max Stirner & Syndicalism, "The Father of Syndicalism" appears (Stirner, Pere du Syndicalisme, Un Centenaire, 1845-1945) in the July 1945 issue of L'Unique, published in Orleans, France, by E. Armand (Vol. I No. 2) Vol. 1, No. 2, 1945 Juillet Stirner, Pere du Syndicallisme Un Centenaire, 1845-1945 Translated by A. S. with English it appears in Freedom through Anarchism Dec. 15, 1945: p. 11

Stephen T. Byington, "Stickers" Begun in "Liberty" in 1904, they were suggested in 1902 as can be seen in a LETTER to HENRY BOOL of ITHACA, NEW YORK from STEPHEN T. BYINGTON of East Cambridge, Mass. dated May 30th, 1902. Byington, in a response to a request from Henry Bool for "a short, crisp sentence" sent him three such, two of which were afterwards used as stickers.

Post Card dated Feb. 7, 1946 Steven T. Byington to Agnes Inglis, in sending me a pile of copies of "The Society of the New Order", 1919, that were never distributed: "Nobody except Fulton ever showed any interest in the proposed Society."

Byington Pamphlet Letter dated Mar. 26, 1946 from Alan Smith to Agnes Inglis: "Byington's pamphlet" - "I would generally agree on its soundness tho I do not think it is a practical Basis for a movement...People will never line up on the basis of any program so complex as Byington's, but they may undergo
[reverse] individual revolutions (in themselves) which will be reflected on their society & so end up on very much the same state as Byington wished....I say that our three lines of attack must be ethical, educational & economic--in that order."

Steven T. Byington

Cantwell, Tom [Page Two] [second carbon] Correspondence ===== data. 1934. October 14. Letter Agnes Inglis (from) to Oscar H. Swede: "So you are the compositor for "Freedom." etc." 1934. November 7. Letter from Oscar H. Swede to Agnes inglis: "***This says you are the editor of "Freedom" published by the "London group." and you say that the "Freedom Bulletin" edited by Thomas H. Keell ceased some time ago. 1934. Letter from Oscar H. Swede to Agnes Inglis - September 20 - Thomas Keell is quoted as saying "The author of "Confessions of an Anarchist" was W.C. Hart, a disgruntled applicant for the post of compositor of "Freedom" which was given to Tom Cantwell, my predecessor ect." 1930, March 22. Letter from Thomas H. Keell to Agnes Inglis: "In January 1903, owing to the illness of Tom Cantwell, the compositor, Alfred Marsh, the editor of Freedom asked me to help in getting out the paper." He then adds in regard to his further relationship with Alfred Marsh, and with Freedom. And tells about the conflict in regard to the war policies of Freedom.

1910 [clipping] With Voltairine de Cleyre and Margaret Haley speaking in Buffalo on the same night Buffalo is getting to know where the advance guard of the women stand. Strangely both these women made the same plea -- for higher education and liberal education for our children and for the right of all citizens to share the responsibilities and privileges of government. One spoke of almost unbelievable civic achievements wrought by a little band of women. The other told how one man -- a martyr had uplifted and renewed a country.

Voltairine de Cleyre Ref. Freedom, England, 1914 Aug. XXVIII, No. 304. In this description the same story is told -- that Voltairine's father returned to Catholicism when and for which reason he put her in a convent. This is not the truth.

V. de C. Carl Nold Correpondence letter placed in Eunice Schuster correspondence envelope letter dated Jan. 8, 1931: "V de Cleyre stood (Carl Nold writes) mentally above E.G. She did not make as much noise as E.G. did but what she did do was done more thoroughly as a private teacher, in private schools, in writing & speeches. She made a trip to England and got acquainted with Kropotkin & Malatesta. [reverse] She was a pupil of Lum & came into the movement through the hanging in Chicago 1887, but developed very fast. A good deal of what E.G. and A. Berkman wrote in later years first went through the hands of V. de C. for approval and correction before it went into print. E.G. tried to attract her hearers with a base drum. V. de C. did it [second card] with a violin." Jan. 8, 1931 Carl Nold answering questions of Eunice Schuster.

This repeats the same story regarding the father of Vo. De C. saying he wanted to make a nun of her: Her mother had to send her to Port Huron where he had work as the other girl, Adelaide, was sick. He put her in the Sarnia Convent, for her schooling, as he could not care for her. He was no unkind, he had to do it.

De Cleyre, Voltairine
re. the Barcelona Case of 1896-1897 In her Box is a letter from her to Senator Wm. E. Chandler of New Hampshire. She enclosed the leaflet in regard to the case. Her letter is dated May 29th, 1897 and is from Phila. 620 N. 8th St. The leaflet is entitled “The Modern Inquisition of Spain”. In it is the Report of the Proceedings of the Court article Trial held in Montjuich Fortress, on December 15, 1896. The trial of 170 members of the Centro de Carreteros (Car Men’s Club) on the charge of a bomb thrown in June 7, 1896.

Letter to Agnes Inglis from Adelaide D. Thayer 204 So. Lansing Street St. Johns, Mich. dated Dec. 27, 1935
Voltairine de Cleyre's mother was born in Rochester, N.Y. Dec. 27, 1837. She was the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pliney Billings. She had three children. Voltairine was the youngest, and Adelaide and Voltairine lived. The other little girl died.

Le Libertaire by Joseph Dejacque A French refugee who wrote most of it himself and brought it out very carefully, 27 numbers, closely printed in small folio very full of matter. June 9, 1858 - Feb. 7, 1861. New York City "Journal de mouvement Social" (includes Utopia L'Humanisphere utopia anarchque, 1858) Second Communist-anarchist paper ever published and first ever published in America Ref: Letter from Max Nettlau, Vienna, 1931, to Agnes Inglis. Apr. 1931

"The Dentons", Ref: Letter to Agnes Inglis from Bertha F. Johnson, dated April 23rd, 1950 "Vanessa, daughter of Shelley Denton and only child. Destler, Chester McArthur 1946 Connecticut College. New London, Conn. See Correspondence: 1940-1946 [clipping] C.M. Destler 1940. Georgia Teacher's College Division of Social Sciences Collegeboro, Georgia Suburb of Statsboro

Destler, Mr. C.M. Letter dated August 24, 1940 answered by me September 1st, 1940 regarding his coming to use the Collection. His permanent address is "Georgia Teachers' College, Collegeboro, Georgia" He is Chairman "Division of Social Sciences." Collegeboro = Suburb of Statesboro He is working on years of the eighties and nineties and Wm. Henry Demerset Lloyd and his time esp. Chicago and Illinois, I take it. He may see Harry Barnard Kletzky on his way for the George Schilling letters. His address = 307 Univ. Club, Madison, Wis. Hayes Foundation Research grant (Mr. Curtis Garrison) [reverse] Chester M. Destler visited the Collection again Dec. 1, 1945, Saturday, working on Henry D. Lloyd again. His article on Shall Reds and Blacks Unite on the Hashell Document sent to Jo Labadie in 1883, which Destler started on in 1940 when he was here is now published in the Pacific Historical Review of December 1945.
"Wm." appears to be crossed out. Person referred to is Henry Demarest Lloyd

Destler, Chester McArthur 1946 "American Radicalism 1865-1901" "Essays and Documents" Monograph No. 3 Connecticut College, New London, Conn. 1946, pages 78-- Chap. V. See Page 82 -- Chap. V. Place Anarchist Section under Destler or in Box on the International Working Mens Assn. See Pacific Hist. Review Dec. 1945, p. 434 See General Library

Chester McA. Destler - Editor 1945 "Shall Red and Black Unite? An American Revolutionary Document of 1883" Reprint: Pacific Historical Review, Vol. XIV, 1945, No. 4, December (434-451 p.) Edited (Program in part) and NOtes by Chester McA. Destler. See Internationals Anarchist Sec. First Box. Socialistic Labor Party.

Chester M. Destler's "Shall Red and Black Unite?" see Note 44. While the article "Clipped from Liberty" is quoted from Liberty it is not the "original" "Liberty" printing and the "Condensed from La Revolte" article also from Liberty is even further condensed in this clipping from same paper -- and added data of the La Revolte report is omitted as it can be found in Liberty, Aug. 20, 1881, Vol. I, No. 2.

C.M. Destler 1945 649 Berkeley College Oct 1945. Yale University New Haven Connecticut on a years leave of absence from teaching in the Department of History and Government at Connecticut College, New London, Conn. Dec. 1, 1945 he came. Sept 1940 he came first.

Destler, Mr. C.M. Chester Sept. 9, Monday and 10 Tues. 1940, Labadie Collection Georgia Teachers' College, Collegeboro, Georgia, Chairman Division of Social Sciences. Working on Henry Demarest Lloyd and labor and socialist movement in Chicago and Illinois especially, in the eighties and nineties. Plans to arrive the 6th, or about then of Sept. 1940. Letter received, and answered by me, Sept 1, 1940. We spent two days going over Philip Van Patten, Schilling, Altgeld.

Destler, Chester M. Summer of 1941, letter of June 9. He is to teach in the Univ. of North Carolina. He plans to work on the Hashell article. He may drop in in August. He spoke at the Southern Historical Association at Charleston at which he spoke of the Spanish materials and John F. Ramsey heard him.

Destler, Chester McA. (Georgia) Ref: "The Labor Populist Alliance in Illinois" (referring to about 1894) Page 589 "Missippi Valley Historical Review, A Journal of American History." This is not in the Labadie Collection.

He financed a paper that was put out by Conrad Frielich, entitled "Landouer Arbeiter zeitung 1896-1897"
ref: CORRESPONDENCE "Johanna Clevans", Sept. 13, 1938

Fabrianovic, Steve stricken by a stroke in Los Angeles, years ago. Johanna Clevans refers to him in her letter dated Feb. 28, 1940 - after Emma Goldman, Saturday, Feb. 17, 1940 had a stroke. After speaking of Emma, Johanna writes: "When I heard of her I reminded myself of old Steve Fabrianovic in Los Angeles who insisted on getting
[reverse] right up after his stroke and on feeding himself and doing things. What a fight he put up - to no avail." She goes on to speak of Minnie, Steve's wife, and of his library which Johanna hopes will one day come to the Labadie Collection.

Card 1 Adolph Fischer: His letter dated November 8th, 1887 to his union - Typographia No. 9, Chicago, written 3 days before he was to die: Saved by Typographia Union No. 9, Chicago until they dissolved in 1946 When Typographia Union No. 9, Chicago dissolved in 1946 they gave this original letter to the Pioneer Aid and Support Association 100 North LaSalle St., Chicago 2, Ill., Irving Abrams
[reverse] Irving Abrams Pioneer Aid and Support Ass'n 100 North LaSalle St., Chicago 2, Ill. wrote a letter dated Nov. 11th, 1946 and sent his letter, enclosing the original letter to the Univ. of Mich for stating it was to be put with the Haymarket material. The communication with the original letter was sent from the President's office by Mr. Robbins to the General Library.

Fischer (Adolph) Card 2. Dr. Warner G. Rice, receiving the communication & original letter turned the same over to Agnes Inglis to be placed in the Labadie Collection with the Haymarket material. Miss Kent, in the office, typed a copy of the letter and also translated it into English. The original letter is hand-written in German script.
[reverse] A copy of the original letter was made in the Yiddish Language and this was published in the Freie Arbeiter Stimme (Free Voice of Labor), New York and Philadelphia, 1946. November 15, Whole No. 2336 No. 46, 47th Year (New Series) Herman Frank, Ed. 45 W. 17th St. N.Y.C. 11 N.Y.
An English translation appears in the I.W.W. Industrial Worker, 1946 Dec. 28 Vol. XXVII, No. 39, Whole No. 566 - Chicago

[manuscript] par delà la mêlée 15 Avril, 1916 France, E. Armand [clipping] Quelques aspects de la Conscience Conscience (accès de): le sentiment de chagrin qu'on éprouve en se rappelant l'âne ou l'idiot qu'on s'est trouvé être en certaines occasions passées. Conscience (trépidations de): la crainte que quelque malin vous joue le même sale tour que vous avez vous-même joué à un autre. Conscience (ironie de la): en considérant le toupet que vous avez de vous attendre à ce qu'autrui se conforme à votre code moral alors que vous, vous le violez si souvent. Conscience (remords de): la sentiment de l'incertitude de la vie et du peu de sûreté qu'offriraient les affaires et la société, si la règle de conduite que vois estimez nécessaire à l'harmonie était aussi violée, en général, que vous la violez quand l'occasion s'en présente. Edward H. Fulton

[Manuscript] (184) 1931 Mai 7 "Le Semeur" French [Clipping] Francisco Ghezzi libéré... Mais qu'est devenue Petrini? Comme nous l'annoncions dernièrement, après une longue persécution, notre camarade Ghezzi a enfin retrouvé momentanément tout au monis, sa liberté. Un mystère plane toujours au sujet des motifs de son arrestation. Aujour-d'hui, comme hier, le gouvernement bolchévique garde sur le cas Ghezzi un mystérieux silence. Que signifie-t-il? Ghezzi est libre, mais nous ne devons point oublier que les prisons russes détiennent des centaines de Ghezzi et parmi ceux-ci, le cas de notre camarade Petrini reste des plus troublants. Où est Petrini? Est-il encore en vie? Le Comité International de défense anarchiste de Bruxelles a adressé au directeur du Guépéou à Moscou, à la citoyenne Péchkova (compagne de M. Gorki), a l'ambassade soviétique à Paris, à la représentation commerciale de l'U.R.S.S. à Anvers une lettre recommandée, dans laquelle il demande des nouvelles de A. Petrini. Nous attendons impatiemment la réponse que sera faite à la demande de reseignements relative à notre camarade. En attendant, nous resterons vigilants et necesserons de dénoncer à l'opinion publique l'arbitraire d'une justice administrative que prétend s'exercer au nom du prolétariat. Pour le Comite: Hem Day

Goldman, Emma Letter dated Feb. 28, 1940. Johanna Clevans: "Did you hear about Emma? Her right side is paralyzed, she is slowly regaining her speech but very down-hearted, as you would imagine. The doctors give her a chance for recovery. She has all the best care, private room, nurses day & night. The comrades are wondering how to pay the bill. When I heard of her I reminded myself of old Steve Fabrianovic in Los Angeles who
[reverse] insisted on getting up right after his stroke and on feeding himself and doing things. What a fight he put up - to no avail - " (etc. referring to his wife Minnie & his library)
(Emma's stroke occurred Saturday Feb. 17, 1940)

Emma Goldman and Free Speech in 1909
Lexington Hall, 116th Street. N.Y.C. Sunday. May 23rd. 1909. Meeting broken up by N.Y. Police. Alden Freeman of East Orange was the Chairman. He with the rest was evicted.
English Hall, East Orange. June 8th. 1909 Speaker: Emma Goldman. Subject: "The Drama as the Strongest Disseminator of Radical Thought." Meeting broken up by the East Orange Police. Alden Freeman's Stable. 101 Munn Ave. East Orange. to which the people were invited to hold the meeting: June 8th. [reverse] The adjourned meeting was held in the Barn. The New York TImes for June 9th. 1909 reported it. "Close to 1000 persons must have listened to her."
A Booklet of the suppressed speeches by Emma Goldman on the Drama and by Alden Freeman on "Paine" for his Centenary was published. And also a Mass Meeting was held in Cooper Union telling about all this. The papers reported all these meetings. The New York Times and the East Orange papers.

Alexander Berkman's Reply to Marcus Graham's attack on Emma's book in "L'Adunata" L'Adunata dei Refrattari Anno XII Nr. 9, March 4, 1933 has an answer to Alexander Berkman under "Giornali-Revisite-Libri" agains Emma's book [reverse] See Carl Nold's Correspondence, 1933, March 10: "In L'Adunata" of March 4 (1933) is an answer to Berkman's article in Freedom about M. Graham. L'Adunata insists that E. Goldman's silly love stories spoiled the propagandistic value of the book. This was also the opinion of the Jewish Freie Arbeiter Stimme in New York...and others. I read and I say "Amen" to it. (Carl Nold).

Goldman, Emma Feb. 1940 (ref. Chi. Tri. Feb. 21, 1940) "She suffered a stroke Saturday night (Feb 17, 1940) [clipping] Emma Goldman Seriously Ill in Toronto After Stroke Toronto, Ont., Feb. 20 (AP) -- Emma Goldman, famous 70 year old radical lecturer and writer, is seriously ill in a hospital here. She suffered a stroke Saturday night at the home of friends. She has been in Canada since May. A Russian born philosophical anarchist, she was deported from the United States to Russia in 1919 after serving prison terms for opposing the world war draft and "urging revolution."

"The State of Utah has polluted itself with the blood of Joe Hill. Is it not terrible that in the 20th century such things are allowed to take place, and yet we are aroused over the crimes committed in Europe, while we remain perfectly indifferent to the crimes at home. The burial takes place in this
[reverse] city tomorrow and Hill will be buried right next to the Chicago Anarchists and Voltairine de Clayre, which is very fitting, I am sure. Emma"

Emma Goldman. DETROIT TIMES, 1917 Tuesday July 10th. "found guilty, Berkman sent to Atlanta. E.G. to Jefferson City"
[clipping] EMMA GOLDMAN GIVEN 2 YEARS Also Draws $10,000 Fine For Opposing Draft; Berkman Gets Same Sentence NEW YORK, July 10--Emma Goldman and Alexander Berkman, the celebrated anarchists, were found guilty of conspiracy to obstruct the operation of the selective draft law by a jury in the United States court last night and sentenced to two years in a federal penitentiary and fine of $10,000 each. The jury deliberated only 40 minutes. The two anarchists had made their own defense, likening their cases to the persecution of Jesus. The speed with which the jury returned a verdict of guilty was a surprise to both. Judge Mayer lost no time in pronouncing sentence, and today the two draft foes were well on their way to prison. Berkman was sent to the Atlanta penitentiary and Miss Goldman to Jefferson City, Mo.

The Word, 1873, May. [clipping] Labor, Finance, Land, Government The Blazing Star; With an Appendix treating of the Jewish Kabbala. Also a Tract on The Philosophy of Mr. Herbert Spencer, and on on New England Transcendentalism. By William B. Greene. This Book fights the battle of Labor Reform in the arena of pure metaphysics, on the question of the Human Soul, and Human Solidarity; showing the "Darwinian Theory" to be the philosophy of Civilized Cannibalism or Malthusian Plutocracy. It is a profoundly able work which scholars and other thinkers will find it their interest to consult. Price $1.50. Also by the same author, Mutual Banking: Showing how Interest on Money can be abolished by Free Competition. Six thousand. Price 25 cents. Yours Or Mine: An Essay to show the True Basis of Property and the causes of its unequal distribution. Twentieth Thousand. By E.H. Heywood: Also, by the same, Uncivil Liberty: Revealing the injustice and impolicy of Ruling Woman without her consent. Sixtieth Thousand. Price 15 cents each. True Civilization: A subject of vital and serious interest to all people; but most immediately to the men and women of labor and sorrow. By Josiah Warren. Price 50 cents. No Treason -- The Constitution of No Authority: A startling exposure of the frauds, usurpations and Tyrannies practiced on the people through our present Federal, State and Municipal governments. By Lysander Spooner. Price 25 cents. A New Monetary System: By Edward Kellogg: Being the original statement and an elaborate exposition of the financial principles now proclaimed by the National Labor Union. Price in cloth, $1.25, in paper 75 cents. Land and Labor: Their relations in nature -- How violated by monopoly. By J.K. Ingalls. Price 10 cents. [clipping] Address Co-Operative Publishing Co. Princeton, Mass.

gt. John Beverley Robinson gt. Cassius V. Cook
1 copy, Greene, Wm. B. 1 copy, Heywood, Ezra H.
[reverse] Note: The Preface explains how this came to be published: A few people used to meet in Worcester, in 1867. They again met in Boston in a convention held in January 1869. At this convention they learned that 20 years before the very conclusions they had reached had, by a different line of argument, been reached by one calling himself "Omega" whose articles had been published in a Worcester County newspaper. The author, "Omega" placed at their disposal these essays reprinted in 1850 & again in 1857. The N.E. Labor Reform League now reprinted them in this 1870 edition as the works of Wm. B. Greene. Ezra H. Heywood, Author: Yours or Mine. Author: The Labor Party. One copy placed "Heywood"

The Word, 1873 May. Vol. 2 No. 1
"Labor, Finance, Land, Government. THE BLAZING STAR; With an Appendix treating of the Jewish Kabbala. Also a Tract on The Philosophy of Mr. Herbert Spencer, and one on New England Transcendentalism. By William B. Greene. This Book fights the battle of Labor Reform in the arena of pure metaphysics, on the question of the Human Soul, and Human Solidarity; showing the "Darwinian Theory" to be the philosophy of Civilized Cannibalism or Malthusian Plutocracy. It is a profoundly able work which scholars and other thinkers will find it their interest to consult. Price $1.50. Also by the same author, MUTUAL BANKING: Showing how Interest on Money can be abolished by Free Competition. Sixth thousand. Price 25 cents. YOURS OR MINE;--An Essay to show the True Basis of Property and the causes of its unequal distribution. Twentieth Thousand. By E.H. Heywood: Also, by the same, UNCIVIL LIBERTY:--Revealing the injustice and impolicy of Ruling Woman without her consent. Sixtieth Thousand. Price 15 cents each. TRUE CIVILIZATION:--A subject of vital and serious interest to all people; but most immediately to the men and women of labor and sorrow. By Josiah Warren. Price 50 cents. NO TREASON--The Constitution of No Authority:--A startling exposure of the frauds, usurpations and Tyrannies practiced on the people through our present Federal, State and Municipal governments. By Lysander Spooner. Price 25 cents. A NEW MONETARY SYSTEM: By Edward Kellogg: Being the original statement and an elaborate exposition of the financial principles now proclaimed by the National Labor Union. Price in cloth, $1.25, in paper 75 cents. LAND AND LABOR:--Their relations in nature--How violated by monopoly. By J. K. Ingalls. Price 10 cents. CO-OPERATIVE PUBLISHING CO., Princeton, Mass."

1893 Ezra H. Heywood attended the 22 Annual Convention of the American Labor Reform League in New York City May 7 & 8, 1893. He caught cold and died a few weeks after buried May 22, 1893, aged 64 The Word. 214. April 1893. Vol. XX (the last issue) says among those expected to attend will be E.H. Heywood, John A. Lant, Henry Beeny, etc. This number refers to the First Convention held in Cooper Union in 1871 (22 years before), when Horace Greeley, Victoria Woodhull & John Siney spoke.

Erza H. Heywood. Died 1893 Member of the Anarchist Club of Boston org. Sept. 18, 1887, as was Josephine and J. Flora Tilton. He was buried from the home of Josephine Tilton - Josephine S. Tilton Huntington Av. Boston
was arrested in 1877 and served 18 mo in prison was arrested in 1883 and was acquitted was arrested in 1890 and imprisoned: was released May 15, 1892. Left a widow & 4 children over
[reverse] "Mr. Heywood attended a labor convention in 1893 New York some three weeks ago." He was born in Princeton Mass. 1829. was well educated Belonged to the anti-slavery group. He believed in States Rights & while depreciating slavery, that it should be abolished by other means than war. Sarah Elizabeth Holmes Bertha F. Johnson thinks that Vega was born about 1883 to Sarah Elizabeth Holmes, but is not sure.
Holmes, Sarah Elizabeth Associated with Benj. R. Tucker's "Liberty." Born Dec. 9, 1847 Died at the end of her 80th year, Jan 8, 1929. See Libertarian "People"

Three Dreams in a Desert Under a Mimosa Tree, by Olive Schreiner. Published in 1897 as a 14 page pamphlet by Sarah E. Holmes, 73 Wenham St. Jamaica Plain, Mass. Sarah E. Holmes published this in booklet form in 1887. Liberty advertises it Dec. 13, 1887, Whole No. 115. Before that Liberty reprinted it, Vol. V, No. 5, Oct. 8, 1887 (109). It was reprinted in Liberty from the Fortnightly Review.

Holmes, Sara E. -- "Zelm" Liberty, Oct. 1907. Sarah Elizabeth Holmes: Born Dec. 9th 1847. Died January 9th, 1929. Ref: Letter to Agnes Inglis from Dr. Bertha F. Johnson of Troy, Pa. Oct. 15th, 1943. She was cremated in Wilkisbarre and buried in Pulnam, Conn. where her parents were buried. Her niece lived in Hartford, Conn. Her daughter's name was Vega Dyer. She was slender and straight. Her short hair turned white, she was gentle and inefficient. She had beautiful big brown eyes, and one was blind.

[reverse] This copy owned by John Beverley Robinson, was given to the Labadie Collection by his son, Beverley Robinson, September, 1940. Another copy was given by Mark Rosenberg.

Sarah Elizabeth Holmes, Publisher. Boston, Massachusetts, 1888. In published Stephen Pearl Andrews' "Science of Society," she says "First published nearly forty years ago" "Introduction dated January, 1851" Stephen Pearl Andrews, tells about this: See "Woodhull & Claflin's Weekly. Aug. 5, 1871 in which S.P.A. says: "I became acquainted with Mr. Warren's peculiar and invaluable scheme of socialistic ideas in 1851: and I wrote and published that same year, I believe, a work entitled "Science of Society," now out of type, which was little more than my exposition of his ideas."
[reverse] S.P.A. in this article goes on to say that he agreed with Josiah Warren in his idea in this work, but that on some points he did not agree with him, as in regard to Fourier's "Combined Order." But his friend, Josiah Warren was very sensitive to criticism or opposition and he desired to refrain from paining him. Nevertheless he could not always keep from disagreeing with him. They did disagree, however,, and the Weekly brings that out in further issues.

Ingalls, John J.
Opportunity. Master of human destinies am I! Fame, love and fortune on my footsteps wait. Cities and fields I walk; I penetrate Deserts and seas remote, and, passing by Hovel and mart and palace, soon or late I knock unbidden once at every gate! If, sleeping, wake--if feasting, rise before I turn away. It is the hour of fate. And they who follow me reach every state Mortals desire, and conquer every foe Save death; but those who doubt or hesitate, Condemned to failure, penury and woe, Seek me in vain and uselessly implore, I answer not and I return no more. -The late John J. Ingalls

Keell (who died 1938 June 26) "Spain and the World" "Chapter 5" of article Spain & Spanish International England and Freedom Group, 1886-1927 speaks of Keell's stand in the war and the history of "Freedom" "Anarchist Ideals From the Root."

Keell, Thomas H. born died June 26, 1938. Assisted Alfred Marsh, editor of Freedom, taking the place of Tom Cantwell, deceased. Keell & Marsh worked together for 12 or 13 years. Marsh died, on the eve of the World War. Keell had been, under Marsh, for several years editing the paper for Marsh. After the death of Marsh he continued editing Freedom. He was editor, publisher and printer. And went on as he had been doing for years, publishing pamphlets.
[reverse] Upon the entrance into the World War, the anarchists split: Keell remained anti-war. "Nettlau" took the German's side. Kropotkin favored Russia. Turner was a strong allied side war supporter. Tcherkesov & Wess and others were pro war. Keell held his ground. Freedom remained anti-war. Keell went to prison; so did Lillian Wolfe under the Defense of the Realm Act. Lillian was released. Their son, Tom, was born.
Whiteway Colony in the Cotswold Hills near Gloucestershire.
see Harry Kelly - "Man!" Oct. 1938 for the above.

Keell, Thomas H. Man! Oct. 1936 Upon the death of Keell which was in June 26, 1938 , by a comrade from England. London Freedom Group, founded in the 90ies around the personality of Kropotkin. "Freedom" founded as an Organ. Keell took on the work, under Alfred Marsh, of publishing, accounting, editing & distributing the paper. And Keell wrote "Notes of the day." Tom took a consistent, an honorable, an uncompromising line of anti-state, anti-government, anti-war activity.
[reverse] He was publisher and distributor of "Spain and the World." "His Firm, neat handwriting on the wrappers to the day of his death remain our last contact with him." Lilian G. Wolfe.

Thomas Keell Wolfe. Son of Thomas H. Keell & Lilian Wolfe. Ref: Freedom England New Series. 1935. Nos. 59 & 60. March & April. With permission of the Author, E. Armand, from the French of Editions de l'en dehors of 1931 - "Le Causemar" The Nightmare.

"LAND and LIBERTY." San Francisco, Calif. 1284 Market Street Vol. I. July No. 15 - 1915
Note: This issue has in it a letter from Tcherkesoff to Wm. C. Owen, the editor. This letter tells about Tcherkesoff's attitude, against Mother Earth and his attitude agreeing with Kropotkin. Wm. C. Owen, commenting upon this, says: "From Tcherkesoff I learn also shy Freedom (England) no longer contains articles by Kropotkin and other noted writers. On the death of March, last October, Keell set himself up as sole dictator and hitherto only moral suasion has been applied to this invader. That I regard as a profound mistake......" In this letter Owen tells, too of T.'s remark about Mother Earth.

"Tcherkesoff has written, from London, praising this paper (LAND and LIBERTY) in the highest terms and expressing his delight that "not all American Anarchosts have taken up the attitude of "Mother Earth"........
Owen goes on explaining why the war is justifyable.
See "Correspondence" Thomas K. Keell" with Agnes Inglis, in which he tells about Kropotkin and John Turner and Tcherkesoff and the other anarchists of England and their opposition to his (Keell's) stand in keeping "Freedom" (England) anti-war. Keell, in Freedom, tells about the historic facts in regard to his connection with "Freedom"
This is likely a continuation of Card 1912.

Note: In the "CORRESPONDENCE" of THOMAS H. KEELL to AGNES INGLIS, he tells about, how, Wm. C. Owen, never had a chance to correct his statements in regard to him because LAND and LIBERTY ceased being published.
Wm. C. Owen had to leave American, at the time of the persecution of the Magon Brothers, and he went to England and became identified with Thomas H. Keell and "Freedom" and the "Freedom Press", until his death.
Of, course, you have to say that Wm. C. Owen cannot be praised for his attack on Keell in a contraversy he was prejudiced on and with no knowledge of Keell's side of the question - taking Tcherkesoff's statement without question.
This is most likely a continuation of Cards 1912 and 1913.

gt. Oscar H. Swede Jan. 1935
[New Series] "Freedom" Eng. Vol. 1. No. 1. May 1930 - "Statement" This article viciously attacks Thomas H. Keell who, in 1914, with "Freedom" had stood out against the War while Kropotkin, Turner and others had not, making a great rift between them. Vol. 1. No. 4 (August) printed "A Protest" pointing out the politely called misstatements made by John Turner against Thomas H. Keell. This Protest is signed by A. Schapiro, M. Nettlau, Emma Goldman, Alexander Berkman &
[reverse] Errico Malatesta. Also on from Freedom Group.
Ed. note: "This wretched business is occupying space in "Freedom" that can be used to much better purpose."
1931 May. No. 13. A letter from "J. Grave" again attacking Keell: "'Freedom' which during the course of the war was somewhat sabotaged by the one who had charge of it."

Joe Labadie Family
[clipping] Lefevre is the name of an [text obscured] widow who keeps a hotel in New Orleans, and is now traveling on a visit to several relatives in the northern states. On Saturday evening she put up at the Union hotel, on Woodbridge street, and retired to rest early, after turning off the gas [obscured text] she supposed. On Sunday morning [text obscured] Labadie, the runner of the hotel, discovered a strong small of gas proceeding from the room, and, after calling on the occupant in English, Spanish, French and German (Pete speaks all those languages, together with three Indian dialects) and not receiving any answer, burst in the door and bore the lady into another room. She was unconscious for some time, and was confined to her bed all day yesterday, but was able to go on her way east today. Moral: Turn your gas completely off before you go to sleep.

Labadie, Jo, Detroit. Eight Hour Day "The Evening Journal." Detroit 1886. April 10. It says - "Joseph A. Labadie of Detroit is building a new house on the west side upon which he has the eight hour system in full operation. Every man employed about the place draws a full days current wages for eight hours work." This house was the cottage on Buchanan Street. The large house, next door, into which they moved was built in 1891. This one build in 1891 was number "74" and is now number "2306." This large house is the one with the attic in which was kept the Labadie Collection material. See "Letter" to Agnes Inglis from Lawrence Labadie dated Dec. 9, 1932.

Labadie, Jo. personal 1886. The Evening Journal - April 10, 1886. "Joseph A. Labadie of Detroit is building a new house on the west side upon which he has the eight hour system in full operation. Every man employed about the place draws a full days current wages for eight hours work." Ref. to Jo, Truth, 1884 and Free Society, Chicago, 1903.

Jo Labadie. Personal Jo and Sophie Labadie -- married August 14, 1877, in Windsor in St. Alphonse Church. See "Jo Labadie" Box of Material for data on Jo's personal and family life. And his Indian and French blood.

Charles Joseph Antoine Labadie, born, Paw Paw, Michigan, 1850, April 19th. An old map of Detroit as it was in 1752 shows the farms of the Labadie family, one branch on the Detroit side of the river and another on the side over by what is now Walkerville. Both Joe and his wife Sophie, came down the line from the old Labadie family, Mrs. Labadie was French on both sides but Joe was Indian from one side. See: Detroit News. 1930, Dec. 7. The original of this Map is in the Clements Library. Clements Library. U of M. - A copy - the reprint in the Detroit News is in the Coll.

Joseph A. Labadie: Anarchist Ref. At the time of the assassination of McKinley in Sept, 1901. Detroit Evening News. Sept. 12, 1901. A rather jolly write - rep of an interview by a News Reporter with Joe as to his being an anarchist. Dr. Tobias Sigel insisted Joe was not an anarchist but Joe insisted he was. Joe shook hands with Emma Goldman just the July previous when she was in Detroit.

Labadie, Jo and Benj. R. Tucker
"Liberty." 1883. June 9. Letter to Benj. R. Tucker from Jo in which he says he is an Anarchist.
Note: This was just before the Congress - the International Workingmens Congress of Pittsburg of 1883. which was attended by himself and Spies and Parsons and for which he and Spies had the communication from Barnette Haskill of San Francisco, with "instructions." And then John Most came and organized the International Working Peoples Association. Some went with him: Parsons, Spies, and Jo did. See "Truth." San Francisco, 1884, and "The Alarm" Chicago (Albert R. Parsons)

1889. Boston, Mass.
Fourth Annual Convention of the A.F. of L.
Jo Labadie was nominated for Vice-President but he declined. He was one who declined, others did, too.
Jo suggested Detroit for the next Convention, which would be in 1890 and Detroit got it.
Jo spoke at the Banquet on "Labor Cranks."

See Jo Labadie Box of Material for Jo Labadies REPORT, as Deligate to the 4th Annual Convention of the American Federation of Labor in Boston Dec. 10, 1889. In his Report he speaks of the Knights of Labor and the A.F. of L. and the Eight Hour Day movement.
Jo was deligate from the Detroit Council of Trades and Labor Unions. And - at this time - he was President of the Michigan Federation of Labor, as its first president.

Jo Labadie was President of the Michigan State Federation of Labor in 1889 and 1890. See 1890 number for his REPORT, in which he spoke of the Haymarket men. Tossy stood against him and Erb for him in their behalf. They were dead but Jo did not forget them.

Joseph A. Labadie was Elected President of the First Convention of the Michigan Federation of Labor, February 1889, and affiliated with the American Federation of Labor. Opened the Proceedings of the Second Annual Convention, February 1890.
Joseph A. Labadie. Member in Good Standing September 1871 of Typographical Union Big Six see no. "2931" of List of Members. About this time, he traveled around. aged 21 - as an itinerant printer.
Typographical Union Big Six New York City Org. 1849. Edgar H. Rogers, Chairman Formerly organized in 1850 with Horace Greeley as President.

Joe Labadie and the Labor Press 1879 and 1880, writing to the Trades - Philadelphia, 1879, Dec. 27, 1880, Jan 10. At this time Joe was interested in the Socialistic Labor Party, and in the Knights of Labor and in the Trades Assembly, - boring, as it were, from within - for the secret upbuilding of the Knights. At the same time interested in the associations themselves and their upbuilding.

Joseph A. Labadie: Michigan T.U., I.T.U. Kalamazoo. 1868. He preserved two photographs of fellow printers who were there with him named Alfred Grandjean and Wm. Bryant, with whom J.A. Labadie went on tramp from Kalamazoo Mich in 1868.

Joseph A. Labadie, the First Organizer of the Michigan Knights of Labor, was commissioned November 1878 by the Grand Master Workman, Uriah S. Stevens. He was again commissioned in December 1879 by Terrance V. Powderly who succeeded U.S. Stevens as Grand Master Workman.
The First Michigan Assembly of the K of L was the Pioneer Assembly, L.A. 901, a secret society. Openly it was called the "Washington Literary Society."

Labadie, Charles Joseph Antoine. Born. Paw Paw, Mich. April 19th. 1850. Died, Detoit, October 7th. 1933. Ref: Detroit News, Oct. 7. 1933. N.Y. "Freedom." November, 1933.

Freiheit. References: 1891. 13 Jahrgang. No. 49. (5 Dezember.) "Detroit." - Article about the In Memoriam Meeting for the Haymarket men. This article speaks of the "geniale Redakteur des Armen Teufel" Robert Reitzel, and of the "Freund Joseph Labadie." The account of Jo is very fine.

Charles Joseph Antoine Labadie, usually called Joe but sometimes called by some of his relatives "Anthony." Printer, Reporter, Editor, Poet. Typo Unionist Socialistic Labor Part Greenbacker ANARCHIST.

Charles Joseph Antoine Labadie. usually called Joe but sometimes called by his relatives "Anthony." in 1879 when he received his Credentials to organize the Knights in Michigan he lived at 121 Porter Street, In 1886 they built their first house on Buchanan Street - cor. Fifteenth, number "74" Later they built another larger house, and owned the two - renting one. 74 became 2306. They lived there always after. Bubbling Waters they did not own until after - about 1908 after the Water Board episode, 1908.

Labadie Family - quoted from "Friend Palmers Early Days in Detroit" Burton Collection. page 623. Louis Labadie married Angelique Campeau, the daughter of an Indian and English wife, in 1759. I do not know if this Louis Labadie had any connection or not, or, if so, what, with Jo.

Joseph A. Labadie as editor of the Advance and Labor Leaf, in 1887. Joe Labadie was editor, then, from some time in July, 1887, till November 19th, 1887, when Judson Grenell took over the editorship and Joe went to work in the typo department of The Sun, according to a clipping from some Detroit paper of Nov. 20 or 21.

Labadie, Jo and the Haymarket see in Detroit & Michigan Section, Box on Politics for: Sam Goldwater's "Envelope" about a meeting held following the death of the Haymarket men in '87. Sam Goldwater made a fine speech. He was followed the Mr. & Mrs. Krieghoff, Jo & C.E. Miller in Weber's Hall. The clipping is worth reading.

Jo and Powderly. K. of L. [clipping] "Warwhoop Joe" is what the Knights of Labor are calling Joseph A. Labadie, delegate from Detroit. It's all on account of a hit he made in a speech yesterday on the Irish resolution. This is what he said: "Ladies and Gentlemen: I wish to say that as all nationalities have been heard on this matter, it is no more than fair and right that I should move the adoption of these resolutions on behalf of the original Americans, as I am representative of them." "Explain the point," said Mr. Powderly, as the speaker took his seat; "the people here to not all understand." "Simply this," said Mr. Labadie; "that only four generations ago my ancestors roamed about this country bedecked in war paint, feathers and tomahawks, and emitted blood-curdling war-whoops from their lips." The audience cheered vociferously at this. "They are whooping yet, Joe," shouted Mr. Powderly, in probably reference to Mr. Labadie's criticism on the general master workman.

Jo Labadie Detroit Anarchist. ---1908. This year of 1908 was an eventful one for Jo, the Post Office held up his mail in April on account of the stickers, which he stuck on his envelopes. These stickers are to be seen in with his Material. -- Mr. Byington's "Anarchist Sticker." Before this he had written for the papers. Look up 1908 clippings in his Material.

Anarchist Stickers. Devised and produced by Mr. Byington. See "Liberty" 1906. April. Vol. XV. No. 9. Whole no. 392. "On Picket Duty" by Benj. R. Tucker. See, also, adv. in read and in (393) Mailed Post-Paid by Benj. R. Tucker.

Jo Labadie and the Water Board episode of 1908. Relative to the suppression of free-speech following the unemployment meeting on Union Square in April (Saturday previous to April 5) 1908. At this meeting a man named Cohen-Silverstein threw a bomb at the police. See "Mother Earth," April 1908. Vol. III. No. 2. The Sunday Tribune, 1908 Apr. 5 says "the throwing of a bomb last Saturday" ... "even the police have been forced to admit that young Silverstein was not an anarchist...." and "sane people are asking by what American rule unemployed men are placed under the especial care of mounted police." -For this clipping see "Scrap-Book" Emma Goldman

Labadie, Jo. Detroit Anarchist. 1908. The Detroit Water Board Affair. Ref. See in the Detroit "Anarchist" Box of Material, the Envelope which has the "Scrap-Book" of Clippings in regard to Jo's job with the Water Board in 1908. This same scrap-book of clippings has in it about Jo having his mail held up and about the Stickers and his advocacy of anarchism.
"Stickers" and Jo Labadie "Ariel" Westwood, N.J. 1908. July.

Jo Labadie. Detroit Anarchist. 1908. His mail held up by the Post Office authorities. "Detroit Journal." April 8, 1908. "Making the Government Ridiculous." He distributed a leaflet "McKinley's Assassination from the Anarchist Standpoint." And also he put "stickers" on his envelopes. So he was "watched" and his mail held up. This just preceded the attempt headed by James Pound to ouste him from his job with the Water Works. The clipping is in the Gentle Anarchist Envelope Detroit Box of Material. Detroit Section.

Joseph A. Labadie as a Poet. see in the Box of his Poems a small booklet entitled "Russian Verses" by Jo Labadie written in 1905. Made into a booklet by Joe's son, Lawrence Labadie on Joe's old printing press in 1932, while Joe was still living. January 9, 1932 Lawrence and Joe came out to be see the "Labadie Collection." It was Joe's last visit to Ann Arbor & his Collection. He autographed the copy for Agnes Inglis.
The digitized version records an annotation by Agnes Inglis regarding how the book came to be in the Collection.

Labadie, Jo and the Labadie Collection

Jo Labadie and the "Labadie Collection"
Associated with "Bubbling Waters" where much of it was kept. And associated with Buchanan St. Detroit. It was begun when Jo and Mrs. Labadie were first married. It was gathered while they lived in the cottage, built in 1886 on the eight hour plan. It was further gathered and kept in the attic of the new house at "74" - and afterwards "2306" Buchanan Street, in the attic. From this attic and from "Bubbling Waters" it came to Ann Arbor. See about Jo in AnnArbor in 1926 "ANN ARBOR."

Labadie Collection "The Public" Sept 11-1932 I gave over to the General Library what we had in the Labadie Collection of the Public as it seemed to me to be unnecessary to have The Public in the Collection as long as it was in the General Library. It was incomplete in the General Library so Volumes V, VI, XVIII, XIX were given to fill in the lacking numbers. over
[reverse] The remaining Volumes, what the Collection had of them, I gave to Miss Hagen to be used to give to other libraries needing them. They consisted of Complete and incomplete Volumes of II-IV, VII-XVII. signed by Agnes Inglis

Arthur Müller Lehning Saturday Oct 24, 1936. James Doll brought up to the Labadie Collection Joris Ivens who was in Ann Arbor with this marvelous cinima pictures of Holland & the Zuider Zee & wheat and of Belgium & the poor people and of rain and all. It was in Oct - 23 & 24 1926 that I received the pictures he sent me for the Collection. See Libertarian section - I had heard that [reverse] Max Nettlau's collection was in Amsterdam, Johanna had written me. I spoke of it to Joris Ivens. He said yes and that he knew the man in charge: Arthur Müller Lehning and said I should write to him & so I did. I wrote to Arthur Müller Lehning. (Agnes Inglis.)

Lehning, Arthur M. (1940-1941) Institute of Social History. 19 Banbury Road. Oxford England. letter - 1941 - Aug. And I sent "Study" to Ralph H. Lutz. Chairman: Directors of the Hoover Library. Stanford Univ. Cal.

Lehning, Arthur Müller - letter dated Dec. 15, 1936. to Agnes Inglis. Eunice Schuster on "Early American Anarchism." - send him a copy - ---"in regard to a publication I am working at and which you might be able to help me. It deals with the "INTERNATIONAL ASSOCIATION." founded in 1855 in London. Josef Dejacque (from "Le Libertaire") belonged to this Association in New York. He also undersigned the program, Other names known are: Claude Pelletier, Tufferd, Debuchy, Victor Lesseine, Montfalcon. "Central Committee" had its seat in London ... The sections in other countries were in correspondence with this Central Committee. Thus it is known that the New York Branch writes [reverse] to the "Central Committee" on May 12th, 1859. As secretary signes: Bernard Hamann. program? documents? look up press of that date. write to Eunice Schuster.

Lehning, Mr. Arthur Müller. c/o Institute for Social History Keizersgracht 264. Amsterdam-Holland. Instriuut voor Sociale Geschiedenis (International Institute for Social History). Lehning, Arthur Müller Ref: "International Association 1855-1859" Appendix VI. April 1856 Page 77. Address to English from French. Strikes versus Co-operatives. stores for supplies, factories for production, etc.

Lehning, Arthur Müller "International Association, 1855-1859" Freedom, England 1914. Mar. "Anarchism" by Max Nettlau (quotes) "Philosophy of Non-Submission" (p. 72). IV 74 pages 12 mo. par Felix P. New York. 1854. Nettlau does not know who Felix P. is but supposes he was one of the French Socialists of the days following 48 who like Dejacque, Bellegarrigue, Coeurderoy, and Claude Pelletier, independent of Proudhon, arrived at Anarchism. "Felix Pignal, the author, a French refugee of December, 1851. He went to America, and [reverse] probably knew Dejacque. At the end of the century he was back in France." Ref: Letter dated August 2, 1939, from Arthur Muller Lehning to Agnes Inglis.

Letter from Max Nettlau to Agnes Inglis dated 1931, April 1, sent from Wien (Austria) Wien, IX./2. Lazerethgasses, 32 (III)/22. (see Correspondence) Regarding Dejacque and Le Libertaire, now in Amsterdam, Holland, in the charge of A.M. Lehning. "The paper referred to is Le Libertaire by Joseph Dejacque, a French refuge who wrote most of it himself and brought it out very carefully, 27 numbers closely printed in small-folio, very full of matter. June 9, 1851 to February 4, 1861, (New York.) This very rare set I have fortunately here with me. It is the second communist-anarchist paper ever published, if L'Humanitaire 2 numbers, July-August, 1841, each 16 pp. in 40, is considered the first one. This I also have got here."

The Individualist. Denver, Colo. Vol. IV. 1889-1890. 1890. No. 23 Frank Q. Stuart (25 cts)
[clipping] "The Economics of Anarchy", by Dyer D. Lum, a fifty-nine page pamphlet, printed in neat style, is before us. We have read the little book through from beginning to end. That portion relating to "Free Capital" we perused many times, and at each perusal we gained new points. The author takes the position with irresistible logic, that the evils from which we suffer are economic in their nature, and cannot be cured by political treatment. Mr. Lum does not deny that land monopoly is at the base of our social ills, and while he concedes that free land or access to natural opportunities would mitigate those ills in a large degree, he demonstrates with great clearness that without free labor, free capital, and free exchange, industrial reform can never be complete. Chapter 7, entitled "Mutual Credit" is very instructive; the writer advocates a system of mutual banking looking to the abolition of gold and silver as the only standard of value, and the issuing of paper money based on the product of labor generally, as a true measure and standard of value. The author's quotations from Proudhon in this connection, as to the proper office of the bill of exchange, are directly in point, showing how commodities may be exchanged, and interest abolished. This Pamphlet should be in the hands of every reformer. It will prove an invaluable assistant to advanced students in economics, for here will be found formulated into a condensed and logical form, the postulates of a science, which is to emancipate humanity from bondage and serfdom.

Mackay, John H. born Greenoch Scotland 1864-Feb.6. He died in Berlin, May 16-1933. Ref.- Letter written to Carl Nold June 20, '33. See "Correspomdence and Donations." Box.
His address before he died was "Berlinerstrasse, 106. Charlottenberg, Berlin, Germany."
Reference: Winn's Firebrand - 1902. December 1. Poem: "Anarchy": first published in 1888 - in "Stürm"

John Henry Mackay. His visit to America. 1893. References to him and his works in "Der Arme Teufel." 1893. July 15. page (259) Vorrede zur Volksausgabe der Anarchisten again. July 22. (continued) (266) Page (277) July 29. Says in German he is to sail July 27th on the Augusta Victoria vom Brennen.

John Henry Mackay "Letter" to George Schumm. 1893. when he came to American that summer on a visit. He left New York to return to Germany, October 14th. 1893. Before he left New York he wrote on Oct. 6 1893. and said that Mr H has sent me some Heinzen copies. He speaks of Mr. Prang. He left the latter part of July 1893 to come to Am. In 1933 came a letter telling of his death from Mr. Preetz. Born in Greenock Scotland 1864. Feb. 6th. Died in Berlin. May 16th. 1933.
Haymarket Ames, Sarah E. Chicago. Anarchist. An Open Letter to Judge Joseph E. Gary "Why the Undertone?" 1893. June 25. being the date of the Unveiling of the Monument in Waldheim Cemetary Mackay

Mackay, John Henry Letter to Benj. R. Tucker and pritned in Liberty (178) No. 22, Feb 21. 1891. "Glad Tidings from Over Sea." "summer of 1889, when I made your acquaintance." "for more than a year (at that time) I had been occupied with --- over
[reverse] (1889) that for more than a year (1889 summer) I had been occupied with the preparation of an extensive work on the movement of Anarchism" Note - resulting in "Die Anarchisten"

Mackay, John Henry. 1893. Visited America. Ref: "Liberty" Edited by Benj. R. Tucker. September. 1893. Vol. IX. 1893 1894. whole number (280) speaks of Comrade Mackay, completing his brief visit to America. Note: Liberty was having a struggle to keep going. After Sept, 1893 it did not appear again until Feb. 24th, 1894. Mackay saw something of the effect of the 1893 panic on the radical movement in Am.
[reverse] John Henry Mackay, visiting America the summer of 1893. is spoken of again in "Liberty" for Dec. 1897. Whole number (357) Vol. XIII.

John Henry Mackay Der Arme Teufel Jr IX. 1893. Nr. 11. (427) 4 Februar. "Was sie singen und sagen" Auch John Henry Mackay neuestes Werk "Die Menschen der Ehe" (A Review) (I think not liked so well) No more appears till Jr. IX. 1893. 29 April. Nr. 23 (439) then is printed (Aus der Dichtungen" dritter Folge) "Ich muss wieder fliegen!" Also "Briefkasten" Chur. Schiveiz. Christian Tarnuzzer. He asks Reitzel if he can come again [reverse] over with Mackay. He writes a fine letter & ends it "Herzl. Grüsse an Dich uxoremque amabilem!" Jr. IX. 1893. 6 Mai. Nr. 24 (440) ("Aus Der Dichturigen dritte Folge.") Im Dienst der Freude" von John Henry Mackay. Jr. IX. 1893. 15 Juli. Nr. 34 (450) John Henry Mackays Vorrede zur Volksausgabe. "der Anarchisten" 22 July 35. (451) (continued) Berlin im Früh yahr 1893 "John Henry Mackay to sail from Hamburg July 27 for America."

Mackay, John Henry met Tucker in Europe in 1889 & also met Robert Reitzel (as his letters to Schumm tell) Met him, Reitzel did, in the month of roses, June 1889. In 1893 Mackay in Sept visited Reitzel in Detroit & went on to visit Schumm.

Mackay, John Henry and his volume of Der Einzige und sem Eigenthum. 1882 edition. see under Stirner (Max) or under Tucker (Benj. R) Ref: Josef Peukert's Erinnerung pps 283-4. In 1890 Josef Peukert met John Henry Mackay in Paris. Later he had a letter from him dated Zurich Oktober 1890, in which J.H.M. asked Peukert to remember him to Otto Rinke & to ask Rinke to write to him and to return his "Stirner". Rinke never did return it. Instead he kept it. He later gave it to Carl Nold, who Sept 13, 1930 gave it to the Labadie Coll. thru Agnes Inglis.

Mackay, John Henry "Gesammelte Werke." In acht Banden. 1911 Tretow bei Berlin: Bernhard Zachs, Verlag. gift -George Schumm. August 1934. Anarchist Section - the Eight Volumes. See "Gesammelte Werke" for details.

"Gesammelte Werke von John Henry Mackay." Erster Band: "Gedichte" Zweiter Band: "Gedichte (Schuss): Neue Gedichte" Dritter Band: "Kinder des Hocklands - Helene - Sturm." Mackay, John Henry & Anarchists allowed in America Mackay came to America in 1893. But by 1903 so great a change had taken place that "Liberty" says it could not happen. Benj. R. Tucker could not have him as a guest - an anarchist! see John Turner Case

LIBERTY. Vol. VI. 1889. Sept. 7th. no. 20 (150) Benj. R. Tucker writes: "NEW WRITERS FOR LIBERTY". "Deputed to visit Europe in the interest of a corporation recently formed for the prosecution of a new literary enterprise, I went as I was bidden, and have just reached home." In Europe I secured the consent of Wordsworth Donisthorpe, of London, formerly the editor of "Jus" and of John Henry Mackay of Zürich, the young German poet and novelist, whose latest work-
[reverse] (whose latest work) "Sturm" has commanded so much admiration, to write each a monthly letter to Liberty With Vilfredo Pareto as its Italian correspondent this journal ..... etc"

Enrico Flores Magon To the Struggle Translated from the Spanish by Ralph Chaplin, while in the Leavenworth Penitentiary of Kansas where they both were. This Poem is to be found in a small pencil-written note book that Ralph Chaplin had in the prison. It is in his Envelope. I.W.W. Section

Poem: To the Struggle by Enrique Flores Magon Translated from the Spanish by Ralph Chaplin: Leavenworth.
We cannot break our chains with weak desire With whines and tears and supplicating cries For not by meekly crawling in the mire The free-winged eagle mounts into the skies
The gladiator victor in the fight On whom the hard contested laurels fall Goes not to the arena pale with fright But steps forth fearlessly defying all over
[reverse] For Victory is a woman sweet and fair Her kiss is won by him who battles best. The virile revel unafraid to bare Before the greatest odds his manly breast.
He only can be free who bravely fights And, foot by foot, takes each embattled hill, Who visions Freedom in the final heights And struggles on with firm unshaken will
So stand erect and scorn to be a slave Cast far from you your old humility. Scatter your chains, give battle bold and brave For your own birthright, Land and Liberty.

Magon, Ricardo Flores. 1922
Ref.: "Voice of the People." Maryland - Baltimore. edited (among others) by Dr and Mrs. Donald R. Hooker.

Magon Brothers. 1931-1932 see the "Nation" Dec 7, 1932 "Tampa's Reign of Terror" by Anita Brenner of the National Committee for the Defense of Political Prisoners. This tells of the widow of Ricardo Flores Magon - Francisca Romero Palacios, aged 52, and her daughter Carolina Vazquez who is a mother of a family of over!
[reverse] young children. On 1931 Nov. 7 in Ybor City a suburb of Tampa a great cigar making center there was trouble. There were arrests - It is a dreadful story of persecution and blackmail. The Daily Worker, Dec. 9, 1932 - page 4 tells about it: these two women inquired for their son & brother & were both arrested.
