Masquerier, Louis. 1873. He attended the American Labor Reform League Annual Convention, May, 1873. the Third An. Con. Bray did not attend but wrote a letter regreting his inability to do so, and Bray was elected as one of the "vice-presidents." Masquerier also attended the Fourth Annual Convention, May, 1874 at which Heywood offered a resolution deploring the Tomkins Square Outrage, 1874 and at which Stephen Pearl Andrews advocated his universal language "Alwata." Masquerier also attended the Fifth Annual Convention, May 1875 and spoke,
Ref: The Word. See "Bray" for details.

Sociology: or The Reconstruction of Society, Government and Property. Published by the Author - 1877. N.Y. Bound Book - Anarchist Section, Labadie Collection Introduction - page 22. "The International Workingmen's Association: - Was increasing rapidly in Europe several years ago. They showed a strong sentiment of the curse of kings, of oligarchies, and of standing armies. But they seemed to have but meagre and indefinite ideas of the form
[reverse] that society should assume. They had a view of some of the principles of a commune which should be self-governed. But still it seemed that if they had succeeded in abolishing existing officers they would again have set up office-holding governments, like pins in a ten-pin alley to be knocked down again in another age. Thus we see the results of the ignorance of man in not seeing that rights are equal, inalienable and individual."
Masquerier, Louis. Greenpoint, N.Y. Boston Investigator XXXIV. 1864/1865 1757 Feb 15, 1865 2203 Sept 3, 1873

Poems - Louis Masquerier. (L.M.) is the initial signed to a poem in the Chicago Socialist. edted by Frank Hirth, Vol. I. No. 11 November 23, 1878. entitled:- "Own Your Own Homesteads." reprinted from the "Liberator" 180 Fulton St. N.Y.

Hymns of THE WRONG LANDLORDRY, HIREAGE. and OFFICERY or OFFICE-HOLDING GOVERNMENTS. -which pages were saved by Bray, also, and in which Bray is mentioned. All of Louis Masquerier's Works are placed in the ANARCHIST SECTION. -MASQUERIER. BOOK & ENVELOPE.
[reverse] "The Wrongs of Landlordry, Hireage and Officery or Office-Holding Government." pages 18-19 "Hymns" "Evans gave to all a homestead stilled cursed by office-holding governments, While Masquerier gives farms and ruling. By voting law by all the people By owner ships throughout every nation - Nulls officers as well as land lords"

Louis Masquerier was an agrarian reformer in the tradition of Tom Paine. He took an active part in the National Land Reform Association as begun in 1844 in New York City by George Henry Evans and his group, advocating
[reverse] "Man's Natural Rights to Land." He opposed Robert Owen's Socialsitic ideas, believing with Evans and Josiah Warren in Individual Sovereignty as the basis of society - like Thomas Jefferson, he felt that "No man has a right to land only."

Anarchist Born in Paris, Ky. on "RECONSTRUCTION of SOCIETY, GOVERNMENT, and PROPERTY." upon the principles of The equality, the perpetuity, and the individuality of the private ownershop of life, person, government homestead and the whole product of labor, by organizing all nations into townships of self-governed homestead demicraries, self-employed in farming and mechanism, giving all the liberty and happiness to be found on earth." Max Metzkow: July 11th 1944 Max Metzkow wrote to Agnes Inglis - He sent a card to be preserved with his Prison Memories. I am preserving the letter, explaining the card, together with the Card with his Prison Memories. The Card is dated January 10, 1865. The Card was written by his father for him when he was 10 years old. The Motto reads - "Do Right and Fear Nothing" over
[reverse] Ever since January 10, 1865 he kept this card with this Motto written for him by his father when he was ten years old. He writes July 11th 1944 and asks that it be preserved with his Prison Memories. I shall so place it. Probably the Motto helped him during those Prison Days of 1880-1883 in Germany. (A.A.I.)

Timmerman Klaus. 1930. He wrote to Alexander Berkman and Emma Goldman in France His address at that time was Benenson's: Napanock. N.Y. They wrote back thanking him for a gift. In Berkmans letter, Berkman spoke warmly of Max Metzkow Timmerman copied the letters & sent copies to Max Metzkow. He sent these copies to Max Metzkow in 1932 over
[reverse] Metzkow aged 89 in 1943 sent these copies to Agnes Inglis in Sept. 1943 with a letter saying about 1898 he himself was living in Buffalo. He left Buffalo and went to New York. And being out of work, he helped Timmerman with Die Stürmvogel. See Correspondence. Metzkow Sept. 1943 See Stürmvogel.

MAX METZKOW.
REF. Letter to Agnes Inglis dated Oct. 26th, 1943
He says that in 1898 he, in 1898, left Buffla in May or June to go to find work in New York City. He passed hrough Rochester, and went to a picnic. He was thinking of the Mollie Maguires and he write an article about them. When he reached New York City, Claus Timmermann was publishing the "STURMVOGEL" Clas Timmermann published the article on the Mollies that Max metzkow had written - either in June, July, or August. (I could not find.)

Max Metzkow - Anarchist. See Letter dated June 1, 1943 - in which he tells of sending the Labadie Collection his Diaries written by him in prison in Germany between Nov 21, 1881 and Nov. 21, 1883. Sidney H. Morse. died Feb. 1903 ref. Liberty Vol XIV. 1903. April. No 8. Whole no. 370 He died at San Mateo, Florida, Benj. R. Tucker writes "He was one of my earliest and most intimate friends. I made his acquaintance shortly after I had made that of Josiah Warren, and was the means of bringing the two
[reverse] to-gether, as a result of which Morse became a thorough believer in Warren's political and economic philosophy and at Warrens death in 1874 came into possession of his personal and literary effects. Since then he has steadfastly upheld the sovereignty of the individual in sundry pamphlets. Notable among the latter was that
Note: the information on this card is continued on Card 2936.

remarkable production "So the Railway Kings Itch for an Empire, Do They?" by a "Red-hot Striker, written at the time of the Pittsburg riots of 1877."....articles signed "H" in the early numbers of Liberty were also from his pen. "He was a poet, an artist, and a thinker."
Note: the information on this card is a continuation of Card 2935.

Sidney H. Morse In 1872 he met Josiah Warren, introduced by Benj. R. Tucker. He became a close friend and follower of Josiah Warren, from 1872 until the death of Warren in 1874. In 1877-1878 he contributed Chips From My Studio to
[reverse] Benj. R. Tucker's magazine "The Radical Review." He wrote in behalf of the Mollie Maguires in 1877.

Perovskia, Sophia. John Most went to prison in England for standing up for her act and publishing his views in Freiheit. in 1881.
This article John Most published in Freiheit in 1881. he reprinted in Freiheit in 1906 -March 10. It was the next to the last issue of Freiheit that John Most ever got out. He gout out the next issue, March 17, 1881. but that very day it was released, he died in Cincinnati while on a lecturing tour.

Most in prison explained to a visitor, the source from which he got his facts for his manuel that was causing such excitement. He waid that not he but Grinell, the State's Attorney, was responsible for instructing the American people, since Grinell was the first to translate the manuel into English. He said the information could be bought in Germany by buying the two books from which he had gotten his information, namely a book issued by the Austrian secretary of war office and one issued by a firm, Hartleben, in Leipsic, Germany.
NOTE: Grinell translated this in order to convict the men being triad, but he did not say he had translated the manuel and from whence the information had been obtained by John Most.

Most, John. born 1846 Feb 5. Augsburg Bavaria.
Note: John Most reprinted in Freiheit, March 10, 1906, the article that he was imprisoned for publishing in Freiheit in 1881 after Sophia Perovskia had blown up Alexander II in 1881. He then published Freiheit in London and was imprinsoned in England at that time. After his release he came to America - in 1882. Hew as imprisoned 19 months in England.
This number -March 10-1806, was the next to the last number of Frieheit that John Most ever issued. He died March 17th, 1906. the day his last issue was released. It is interesting that the month he died Emma Goldman started "Mother Earth." March-1906. --OVER--
[reverse] May-1906, Alexander Berkman came out of the Penitentiary. Two month after the death of John Most. So they never saw each other again after 1892.
This is interesting in a way for Most did not approve of Berkman's act There was quite a contraversy about it
F. Thaumazo, who was on Most's side and published quite a few things in Freiheit, wrote "The Martyrdom of Berkman" after Berkman came out and after he wrote his "Prison Memoirs."
This is one of the dramas of the movement

Most, John born in Augsberg Bavaria, 1846, Feb. 5 died Mar. 17, 1906 in Cincinnati Came to America in 1882 In 1883 founded the International Working Peoples Association in Pittsburg Spies and Parsons both present as delegates. see Carl Nold's correspondence and what he says of Most and of Max Metzkow. Look up Max Metzkow, see Donation lists. Max Metzkow set up the type in London in 1880 for Freiheit

John Most and his publishing as a reprint Karl Heinzen's defense of regicide, as Most did just prior to the assassination of McKinley - and it was held against him in his trial. REFERENCE: "LIBERTY" Benj. R. Tucker 1903 Vol. XIV. No 11, Whole no (373) - July.

Most, John and Karl Heinzen. Karl Henizen wrote a book (in German) that, translated, is entitled "Murder and Liberty." It was published in 1853, as a Contribution for the "Peace League of Geneva." In 1901 in the hysteria that followed the assassination of McKinley, Most was arrested and convicted and imprisoned. What they had against him was a reprint of this 1853 book of Heinzen's! "LIBERTY" Edited by Benj. R. Tucker, speaks of his arrest. Vol. XIV. 1903-1904 - July, 1903 (373)

[clipping] Zenzl Meuhsam Voilà deux ans qu'Erich Mühsam est tombé, victime de la barbarie naziste. Est-il possible que sa veuve, partie en Russie pour publier ses oeuvres de son compagnon, ait été arrêtée, après avoir remis les manuscrit d'Erich et se trouve actuellement emprisonnée on ne sai où? Est-il exact que l'instrument des persécutions auxquelles elle est en butte soit une certaine Hélène Stassova, une des figures les plus connues de bolchevisme, collaboratrice de Lénine, présidente du Secours Rouge International et que guida Zelzl Mühsam dans Moscou? En laissant pénétrer celle-ci en U.R.S.S., les digigeants de ce pays savaient partaitement bien qu'elle affirmerait et proclamerait qu'Erich Mühsam était né et est resté anarchiste jusqu'à la fin. Il y a dans cette façon de faire un arbitraire et un muflerie que soulèvent le dégoût de quiconque a le coeru bien placé, ami ou non de l'U.R.S.S. Traitera-t-on encore celui qui s'indigne devant de tels faits de "contre-révolutionnaire"?

Mühsam, Erich Letter to Agnes Inglis from Carl Nold, dated April 10, 1933. "Just received the news that Erich Mühsam was interned - to be tried for treason." "Rudolph Rocker, who wrote the life of John Most, was more lucky. He escaped in due time to Switzerland."

Correspondence: Thomas H. Keell to Anges Inglis, July 19, 1937. "XXX is Max Nettlau and the other old member of the Freedom Group is myself. In many publications in the earlier days, including Freedom, Nettlau frequently signed himself XX (two asterisks as a rule) to camouflage his identity. Now he does it because he still lives in Vienna, and thinks it safer not to put his name to anything of the anti-fascist character."

Eight Hour Movement & John Orvis. "The Labor Cause." "The Question No. III" "The American Workman." Boston 1869. July 10. "Extracts" Typewritten. John R. Commons Commons Coll. Labor Material and Newspapers. Hist. Lib. U.S. Mss 21A Madison, Wis. Room 102 - over -
[reverse] "The Labor Cause The Question No. III" John Orvis. Note: [That was as far as he got!] (A.A.I.) He objected to giving the eight hours movement the prominence which its leaders claimed for it. He maintained that hours of labor had nothing to do with the "infamous wage-slave system, the source of all the laborer woes." He said it would be impossible to conduct all labor on the eight hour plan, in this system. He said "palliatives will not do." His own solution was "Co-operation" but "equitable" "between capitalists and laborers."
"Extracts on the History of Labor from the 'American Workman' Boston. May 1869-Aug. 1872." by John R. Commons
